body: According to letters the Rev. Edmund Brady found in the attic of the rectory, the pipe organ at St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn had begun to falter early in 1972. By the end of that year, many of the keys would not work. Others would not shut off. ''You would turn the organ on, and two-thirds of the pipes would start playing,'' said
title: BUSHWICK PARISH RESTORING ORGAN TO PAST GLORY

body: Two girls were shot and killed in a Brooklyn apartment that was apparently used by a narcotics ring. The girls, Evette Guardiola, 17 years old, and Lillian Rodriquez, 16, were found last night at 370 Bushwick Avenue. ... A Brooklyn boy, Adanan Hasan, 15, was shot dead at 11 A.M. with a gun he and two friends had in a car near Prospect Park. ... Two
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: By Robert E. Marks Irving C, a 45-year-old double amputee confined to a wheelchair, spent last Christmas in the front seat of an old car parked in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. He has been paralysed below the waist since a shooting incident in 1965, when he was 27. A few years later, when he developed circulatory problems, his legs
title: A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND; FROM THE WHEELCHAIR, HE SEES REASON TO HOPE

body: AQUIET revolution in housing administration and urban policy o ccurred in New York City four years ago when the city's housing a gency took over the management of tax-foreclosed residential p roperty. The Department of Real Estate previously had this task, and for commercial buildings it still does. Typically, it would hold property a year or more,
title: HOW CITY REDUCES FORECLOSURE STOCK

body: THE heartbreaking plight of New York's homeless grew that much worse last week as temperatures dropped. With city shelters swollen by about 4,400 such people, and uncounted thousands still on the streets, there were new calls for action. An interdenominational group, the Partnership for the Homeless, urged Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo to replace
title: RENOVATING THE CITY'S SHELTER PROGRAM

body: Down on the Farm In Bushwick T he picture emerging from the awards ceremony at City Hall yesterday was of a city filled with people spading, hoeing, seeding, pruning, weeding and harvesting. This may not be everybody's image of New York. It describes, however, the work of 49 neighborhood groups that include hundreds of people. They were winners of
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Less than 48 hours after Mayor Koch and Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced new measures to curb crime in the public schools, a 16-year-old student at Eastern District High School in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn was critically wounded when he resisted a robbery attempt by two schoolmates. The shooting last week followed a Nov. 10
title: A BACK-TO-BASICS PLAN FOR SCHOOL CRIME

body: A 16-year-old student who refused to give up his gold chain was shot and seriously wounded yesterday by two other students outside the cafeteria of Eastern District High School in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said. One of the fleeing suspects, also 16, was arrested by a police officer patrolling outside the school after the youth
title: BROOKLYN YOUTH SHOT BY ROBBERS AT A HIGH SCHOOL

body: The body of a 10-year-old girl was found at a construction site in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday morning, and hours later detectives charged her 28-year-old cousin with the murder after rescuing him from a group of enraged relatives, the police said. The suspect, Martin Banks of 2091 Amsterdam Avenue, had been sought by the police from
title: GIRL FOUND SLAIN; COUSIN HELD

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violating the health code. In addition, the department named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and five that were closed after failing to do so. VIOLATIONS Chicken Burger World, 404 Ave. of the Americas. Tavola Calda da Alfredo, 285
title: 24 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

body: With a flurry of office parties, some impromptu speeches and a great deal of back-slapping, six city employees have received awards for outstanding public service. The first part of each award was an engraved plaque. The second part was a tax-free check for $5,000. This was the 10th consecutive year that the Fund for the City of New York has
title: 6 CITY WORKERS GIVEN PUBLIC SERVICE AWARDS

body: A Queens woman has been indicted on a charge of posing as a physician, and a legitimate doctor has been accused of aiding her in unlawful deception, officials said yesterday. Edward J. Kuriansky, deputy state attorney general, said a Brooklyn grand jury had listed 50 counts against the woman, Elvira Andramuno, 45 years old, of South Ozone Park, and
title: THE CITY; Woman Accused Of Acting as Doctor

At a news conference in Albany, the Mrs. Sullivan, who is also the candidate of the Conservative and Right to Life Parties, endorsed the Reagan Administration's
title: U.S. SHOULD REMAIN IN U.N., G.O.P. SENATE HOPEFUL SAYS

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: Edolphus Towns, the deputy borough president of Brooklyn, won the Democratic nomination for the 11th Congressional District. He defeated two others in the race to fill the seat vacated by Representative Frederick W. Richmond. Mr. Towns is almost assured of election in November in the district, which is overwhelmingly Democratic and which was
title: TOWNS WIN IN BID FOR RICHMOND'S SEAT

body: While battle lines were late in forming in the 11th Congressional District after former Representative Frederick W. Richmond was forced to withdraw his bid for re-election, Edolphus Towns succeeded in gaining the Democratic organization's support for the primary tomorrow. In addition, Mr. Towns also received the support of insurgents. For example,
title: DEMOCRATS SEEK RICHMOND'S SEAT IN A 3-WAY RACE

body: Most public school teachers in New York State enjoy their work, think they are doing a good job and are proud of their profession, but nearly half say they would choose another field if they had it to do over again, according to a survey conducted by The New York Times. Evidence that even dedicated teachers would look elsewhere is one sign of what
title: SURVEY OF TEACHERS REVEALS MORALE PROBLEMS

body: When the men of the 23d Precinct talk about their female colleagues, Eileen Hemmerich's name invariably comes up. The men may not know the facts of the incident involving Officer Hemmerich last November - conflicting versions abound -but they talk about it all the same. To them the incident illustrates why, 10 years after women came on uniformed
title: RESENTMENT STILL RIDES ALONG WITH WOMEN ON PATROL CARS; Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: More than 350 courses in women's studies at 53 educational institutions and women's centers throughout the city are included in a new publication from the New York City Commission on the Status of Women. Entitled ''Guide to Women's Studies,'' the 72-page booklet offers a wide-ranging selection. The courses are on such topics as: starting a
title: COURSES FOR WOMEN IN THE CITY

body: Eleven firemen were injured yesterday when a two-story burning vacant building collapsed in the Bronx, officials said. The fire, at 1590 Jesup Avenue in the Highbridge section, was reported at 1:08 P.M., according to John Mulligan, a Fire Department spokesman. He said that the injured firemen had been taken to the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical
title: THE CITY; 11 Firemen Injured As Building Falls

body: A 24-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged last night in the death of her 23-month-old daughter, the police said. The woman, identified as Nolin Delgado of 890 Flushing Avenue in the Bushwick section, was arrested and charged with criminally negligent homicide 10 hours after she took her daughter, Rosa, to Greenpoint Hospital with multiple bruises,
title: Mother Held in Child's Death

body: Ground was broken yesterday for a $4.2 million police station house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. Ana Garcia, a police spokesman, said the two-story glass and steel building, at 480 Knickerbocker Avenue, would be completed in about two years. The new station house will replace one built at Wilson and DeKalb Avenues in 1895, when the borough
title: THE CITY; Brooklyn Getting New Police Station

body: An off-duty police officer, who was walking with his wife and two children last night in Brooklyn, shot and killed a man who lunged at him with a knife, the police reported. A spokesman for the Police Department, Sgt. Edwin Leschack, said that shortly after 10 P.M. the officer, Larry Zontini, who was scheduled to go on duty in the communications
title: Officer Kills Assailant While Family Watches

body: Shirley Chisholm's New Job M ount Holyoke College will be the next stop for Representative Shirley A. Chisholm of Brooklyn when she hits the trail out of Congress at the end of the year. The women's college in South Hadley, Mass., has named her Purington Professor, a position previously held by W.H. Auden, Bertrand Russell and Arna Bontemps, among
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: The Brooklyn church, on a dead-end street, was built inside an old auto shop. The original building, on nearby Bushwick Avenue, burned in 1975. Yesterday morning a mass was offered at Our Lady of Lourdes. A block and a half away, at the church's convent on Aberdeen Street, five women swathed in white were about to commit themselves to a mission as
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Entering a Life Of Contemplation

body: Preserving the Past E ach year up to 2,000 buildings and houses are demolished in this ever-changing city, and as they disappear so do irreplaceable architectural nuggets. To preserve a cartouche or a segmented window hood, a cottage industry of recyclists has arisen - men and women some have taken to calling ''savers of the lost arch.'' One is
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Three men posing as armored-car guards held up the Miller Bakery at 176 Woodward Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday afternoon and took $17,000 at gunpoint. One of the men, identified as Keith Terry, 21 years old, of 300 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, ran into a nearby building, where he grappled with a retired police officer, Paul Teknus, 51. Mr.
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: The Brooklyn District Attorney dropped charges yesterday of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide against a youth accused of killing a teacher who had intervened in a home-room fight. The youth, 17-year-old Anthony Davis of Brooklyn, still faces minor assault charges stemming from the clash on March 19, 1981, in which John Sette, a teacher
title: Brooklyn Youth Clear Of Teacher Homicide

body: For the first time in at least a decade, students in the New York City public schools exceeded the national averages in both reading and mathematics scores, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the city's Board of Education. Results of tests given in April show that 51 percent of the students tested in reading and 56.5 percent in
title: STUDENTS IN CITY TOP U.S. LEVELS FOR SCHOOL TESTS

body: Seminar Center With Rabbits, Riv Vu It was news to Brooklyn Botanic Garden officials when they read in his recent autobiography, ''Yes to Life,'' that Corliss Lamont had arranged for the Garden to inherit his 30-acre estate in Ossining. It includes, he said fondly, ''woodlands, trails, a pond and a brook, rabbits, squirrels, occasional deer and a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: About 20 percent of New York City's population - 1.4 million people - has been receiving benefits from income-support programs, according to a new Human Resources Administration study. "This is the first time a total unduplicated count of people receiving aid from income-support programs has been available," the city agency said. The programs
title: CITY AGENCY REPORTS 1.4 MILLION GRANTED INCOME-AID BENEFITS

body: Several companies in the New York metropolitan area where illegal aliens were rounded up last week reported yesterday that many of them had been released from custody and were back at their old jobs. And some companies said that few, if any, unemployed American citizens had applied for the jobs that were freed by the raids and which the Government
title: ALIENS SEIZED BY U.S. REPORTED BACK AT WORK

body: An arts program in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn will receive $500 on Tuesday to enable its teen-age dancers to buy costume material for a series of performances this summer. The money was one of 61 awards, amounting to $16,499, announced last week by the nonprofit Citizens Committee for New York City. In its self-help neighborhood program, the
title: Citizens Committee Awards $16,499 to Groups in the City

body: Swooping in as workers began morning shifts, Federal immigration agents apprehended nearly a thousand illegal aliens yesterday at job sites around the nation in what the Government said was an effort to recapture higher-paying jobs for unemployed American citizens. In New York and New Jersey, Immigration and Naturalization Service agents raided at
title: NEARLY 1,000 ARE SEIZED IN A; JOB SWEEP OF ALIENS

body: The Brooklyn Democratic leader, Meade H. Esposito, yesterday called on Representative Frederick W. Richmond, the subject of a Federal investigation, to ''resign immediately for the good of the Democratic Party.'' Mr. Esposito, a sponsor of Mr. Richmond's transition from a wealthy businessman to a holder of a public office, , said he was ''very
title: RICHMOND IS ASKED BY ESPOSITO TO QUIT FOR THE PARTY'S SAKE

body: Fire swept through a frame dwelling in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, killing a 7-year-old girl and critically injuring a 4-yearold boy, officials said. Firefighters pulled the two children from the smoke-filled topfloor apartment of the three-story building at 25 Cornelia Street. The girl, La-toya Singleton, was dead on arrival at Wyckoff
title: THE CITY; Girl Dies in Fire, Boy Badly Injured

body: The opening scene for ''All in the Family,'' a street of tidy, if tediously uniform, row houses, was filmed in Glendale, Queens, many residents contend. Although the producers of the television program decline to confirm or deny that, the residents continue to believe it. ''There is this joke that this is Archie Bunker territory,'' said Terence G.
title: RIDGEWOOD-GLENDALE OPENS ITS DOORS

body: Two supermarket corporations will donate a total of $13,000 worth of food to the elderly poor under a settlement of cases in which they were charged with bribing New York City inspectors to overlook pricing or other violations at stores in Brooklyn. One company, Shell-Mar Foods, which operates a Key Food store near Prospect Park, will donate
title: THE CITY; Elderly Get Food In Court Accord

body: Increasingly in the pentagonal-shaped enclave of northern Brooklyn known as Bedford-Stuyvesant, there is deep concern about the many residents, particularly the aged, who are threatened by the loss of their property because they cannot pay the taxes. City housing officials recently announced tax foreclosures on 50 percent of the 6,000 one-family
title: TAX DEFAULTS CAST A PALL

body: The Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm will open a new $10 million building tomorrow in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn. The new building, which will house 73 residents, has nursing and recreational facilities for an additional 180 elderly people. The home, which was founded in 1912, is situated at 871 Bushwick Avenue, where
title: NEW FACILITY FOR AGED TO OPEN

body: For much of the last five years, Darryl Witherspoon has lived in institutions for young criminals. He has lived in big ones and small ones, in the city and in the country. He has been in some for a year or so and slipped away from others shortly after being assigned a bed. At the age of 19, he has sampled nearly the entire range of institutions
title: FOR DARRYL, INSTITUTIONS WERE SCHOOLS FOR CRIME; Juvenile Crime Fifth of six articles.

body: A class-action lawsuit was initiated yesterday in an attempt to force the city to upgrade and expand its shelters for homeless women so that they meet the court-approved standards already observed for homeless men. According to the suit, brought by Robert M. Hayes, a lawyer for the Coalition for the Homeless, an association of voluntary agencies,
title: SUIT SEEKING TO UPGRADE CITY SHELTERS FOR WOMEN

body: Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of New York and the first black woman to win a seat in Congress, said today that she would not seek another term. ''I'm hanging up my hat,'' she said in an interview. Mrs. Chisholm, who has represented the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick sections of Brooklyn since 1968, said her decision was motivated
title: MRS. CHISHOLM PLANS TO RETIRE FROM CONGRESS

body: A gunman trying hold up a Brooklyn candy store at 1195 Halsey Street in the Bushwick section fatally shot the owner in the chest and escaped. The victim, identified as Miguel Montalvo, 40 years old, of 526 Wilson Avenue, was taken to Wyckoff Hospital, where he died shortly after the 3:30 P.M. shooting. ... A two-alarm apartment fire at 10 A.M.,
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: Three children were killed yesterday in a fire on the top floor of a three-story building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The children's mother was able to rescue a fourth child, authorities said. The victims - 10-month-old Miguel Negron and his brothers, Wally, 2years, and Lu is, 3 - died when the ceiling of the house, at 137 Irving Avenue ,
title: 3 Children Are Killed In a Blaze in Brooklyn

body: For four months, New York City corrections officials have released prisoners from the Rikers Island jail complex for part of each workday to serve on crews that clean and rehabilitate parks. The Koch administration was initially concerned about the reaction in affected neighborhoods, and so while officials are now eag er to discuss the program,
title: CITY IS USING RIKERS PRISONERS TO CLEAN PARKS

body: Seven New York City teen-agers who symbolized President Reagan's call for ''private-sector initiatives'' met with the President yesterday in a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The young men and women saw Mr. Reagan just before he spoke at a luncheon of the New York City Partnership Inc. in the hotel's grand ballroom. All of them had obtained
title: REAGAN TALKS TO CITY YOUTHS ABOUT JOBS

body: Just days after a State Supreme Court justice f ound that New York City's shelte r program for homeless men was acceptable for this winter, a vol unteer lawyer is in a dispute with the city over its plans for hom eless women. The city now runs three shelters for homeless women, with a capacity of 340, including a new one on East Third Street that
title: LAWYER TERMS SHELTERS FOR WOMEN INADEQUATE

The women's college in South Hadley, Mass., has named her Purington Professor, a position previously held by W.H. Auden, Bertrand Russell and Arna Bontemps, among
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: The Brooklyn church, on a dead-end street, was built inside an old auto shop. The original building, on nearby Bushwick Avenue, burned in 1975. Yesterday morning a mass was offered at Our Lady of Lourdes. A block and a half away, at the church's convent on Aberdeen Street, five women swathed in white were about to commit themselves to a mission as
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Entering a Life Of Contemplation

body: Preserving the Past E ach year up to 2,000 buildings and houses are demolished in this ever-changing city, and as they disappear so do irreplaceable architectural nuggets. To preserve a cartouche or a segmented window hood, a cottage industry of recyclists has arisen - men and women some have taken to calling ''savers of the lost arch.'' One is
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Three men posing as armored-car guards held up the Miller Bakery at 176 Woodward Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday afternoon and took $17,000 at gunpoint. One of the men, identified as Keith Terry, 21 years old, of 300 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, ran into a nearby building, where he grappled with a retired police officer, Paul Teknus, 51. Mr.
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: The Brooklyn District Attorney dropped charges yesterday of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide against a youth accused of killing a teacher who had intervened in a home-room fight. The youth, 17-year-old Anthony Davis of Brooklyn, still faces minor assault charges stemming from the clash on March 19, 1981, in which John Sette, a teacher
title: Brooklyn Youth Clear Of Teacher Homicide

body: For the first time in at least a decade, students in the New York City public schools exceeded the national averages in both reading and mathematics scores, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the city's Board of Education. Results of tests given in April show that 51 percent of the students tested in reading and 56.5 percent in
title: STUDENTS IN CITY TOP U.S. LEVELS FOR SCHOOL TESTS

body: Seminar Center With Rabbits, Riv Vu It was news to Brooklyn Botanic Garden officials when they read in his recent autobiography, ''Yes to Life,'' that Corliss Lamont had arranged for the Garden to inherit his 30-acre estate in Ossining. It includes, he said fondly, ''woodlands, trails, a pond and a brook, rabbits, squirrels, occasional deer and a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: About 20 percent of New York City's population - 1.4 million people - has been receiving benefits from income-support programs, according to a new Human Resources Administration study. "This is the first time a total unduplicated count of people receiving aid from income-support programs has been available," the city agency said. The programs
title: CITY AGENCY REPORTS 1.4 MILLION GRANTED INCOME-AID BENEFITS

body: Several companies in the New York metropolitan area where illegal aliens were rounded up last week reported yesterday that many of them had been released from custody and were back at their old jobs. And some companies said that few, if any, unemployed American citizens had applied for the jobs that were freed by the raids and which the Government
title: ALIENS SEIZED BY U.S. REPORTED BACK AT WORK

body: An arts program in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn will receive $500 on Tuesday to enable its teen-age dancers to buy costume material for a series of performances this summer. The money was one of 61 awards, amounting to $16,499, announced last week by the nonprofit Citizens Committee for New York City. In its self-help neighborhood program, the
title: Citizens Committee Awards $16,499 to Groups in the City

body: Swooping in as workers began morning shifts, Federal immigration agents apprehended nearly a thousand illegal aliens yesterday at job sites around the nation in what the Government said was an effort to recapture higher-paying jobs for unemployed American citizens. In New York and New Jersey, Immigration and Naturalization Service agents raided at
title: NEARLY 1,000 ARE SEIZED IN A; JOB SWEEP OF ALIENS

body: The Brooklyn Democratic leader, Meade H. Esposito, yesterday called on Representative Frederick W. Richmond, the subject of a Federal investigation, to ''resign immediately for the good of the Democratic Party.'' Mr. Esposito, a sponsor of Mr. Richmond's transition from a wealthy businessman to a holder of a public office, , said he was ''very
title: RICHMOND IS ASKED BY ESPOSITO TO QUIT FOR THE PARTY'S SAKE

body: Fire swept through a frame dwelling in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, killing a 7-year-old girl and critically injuring a 4-yearold boy, officials said. Firefighters pulled the two children from the smoke-filled topfloor apartment of the three-story building at 25 Cornelia Street. The girl, La-toya Singleton, was dead on arrival at Wyckoff
title: THE CITY; Girl Dies in Fire, Boy Badly Injured

body: The opening scene for ''All in the Family,'' a street of tidy, if tediously uniform, row houses, was filmed in Glendale, Queens, many residents contend. Although the producers of the television program decline to confirm or deny that, the residents continue to believe it. ''There is this joke that this is Archie Bunker territory,'' said Terence G.
title: RIDGEWOOD-GLENDALE OPENS ITS DOORS

body: Two supermarket corporations will donate a total of $13,000 worth of food to the elderly poor under a settlement of cases in which they were charged with bribing New York City inspectors to overlook pricing or other violations at stores in Brooklyn. One company, Shell-Mar Foods, which operates a Key Food store near Prospect Park, will donate
title: THE CITY; Elderly Get Food In Court Accord

body: Increasingly in the pentagonal-shaped enclave of northern Brooklyn known as Bedford-Stuyvesant, there is deep concern about the many residents, particularly the aged, who are threatened by the loss of their property because they cannot pay the taxes. City housing officials recently announced tax foreclosures on 50 percent of the 6,000 one-family
title: TAX DEFAULTS CAST A PALL

body: The Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm will open a new $10 million building tomorrow in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn. The new building, which will house 73 residents, has nursing and recreational facilities for an additional 180 elderly people. The home, which was founded in 1912, is situated at 871 Bushwick Avenue, where
title: NEW FACILITY FOR AGED TO OPEN

body: For much of the last five years, Darryl Witherspoon has lived in institutions for young criminals. He has lived in big ones and small ones, in the city and in the country. He has been in some for a year or so and slipped away from others shortly after being assigned a bed. At the age of 19, he has sampled nearly the entire range of institutions
title: FOR DARRYL, INSTITUTIONS WERE SCHOOLS FOR CRIME; Juvenile Crime Fifth of six articles.

body: A class-action lawsuit was initiated yesterday in an attempt to force the city to upgrade and expand its shelters for homeless women so that they meet the court-approved standards already observed for homeless men. According to the suit, brought by Robert M. Hayes, a lawyer for the Coalition for the Homeless, an association of voluntary agencies,
title: SUIT SEEKING TO UPGRADE CITY SHELTERS FOR WOMEN

body: Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of New York and the first black woman to win a seat in Congress, said today that she would not seek another term. ''I'm hanging up my hat,'' she said in an interview. Mrs. Chisholm, who has represented the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick sections of Brooklyn since 1968, said her decision was motivated
title: MRS. CHISHOLM PLANS TO RETIRE FROM CONGRESS

body: A gunman trying hold up a Brooklyn candy store at 1195 Halsey Street in the Bushwick section fatally shot the owner in the chest and escaped. The victim, identified as Miguel Montalvo, 40 years old, of 526 Wilson Avenue, was taken to Wyckoff Hospital, where he died shortly after the 3:30 P.M. shooting. ... A two-alarm apartment fire at 10 A.M.,
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: Three children were killed yesterday in a fire on the top floor of a three-story building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The children's mother was able to rescue a fourth child, authorities said. The victims - 10-month-old Miguel Negron and his brothers, Wally, 2years, and Lu is, 3 - died when the ceiling of the house, at 137 Irving Avenue ,
title: 3 Children Are Killed In a Blaze in Brooklyn

body: For four months, New York City corrections officials have released prisoners from the Rikers Island jail complex for part of each workday to serve on crews that clean and rehabilitate parks. The Koch administration was initially concerned about the reaction in affected neighborhoods, and so while officials are now eag er to discuss the program,
title: CITY IS USING RIKERS PRISONERS TO CLEAN PARKS

body: Seven New York City teen-agers who symbolized President Reagan's call for ''private-sector initiatives'' met with the President yesterday in a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The young men and women saw Mr. Reagan just before he spoke at a luncheon of the New York City Partnership Inc. in the hotel's grand ballroom. All of them had obtained
title: REAGAN TALKS TO CITY YOUTHS ABOUT JOBS

body: Just days after a State Supreme Court justice f ound that New York City's shelte r program for homeless men was acceptable for this winter, a vol unteer lawyer is in a dispute with the city over its plans for hom eless women. The city now runs three shelters for homeless women, with a capacity of 340, including a new one on East Third Street that
title: LAWYER TERMS SHELTERS FOR WOMEN INADEQUATE
